commentBody: I know that the answer to 39D is not especially friendly to constructors, but I'm surprised it's only appeared twice previously - in 1952 and 1961 - in the NYT crossword.

Despite the fitness theme this puzzle was not a strenuous workout, and didn‚Äôt make me feel like a dumbbell, but I had fun with it nonetheless.  I liked the clues for BARISTA and USEDPOT. I also like having the revealer at 1D.  That was a little bit of a curveball
Took me far too long to catch on! ü§¶üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Still enjoyed it lots. Thanks!

Ah, Cinderella. Glass slippers schmippers, if your prince is a sports buff, twenty years later you‚Äôll be turning into a pumpkin at midnight when it‚Äôs a ball game that‚Äôs in overtime, not a ball. 

Or so I‚Äôve heard.

Some of us may be TONED and FIT and all those things, but the puzzle also included some others of us, who are

ROUND!
What‚Äôs the deal with 36D?  Is that not still how to start a long-distance call in the present day?
Glad I got SRO and ENT on the crosses because I had no idea what those were
5D is not an uncommon mistake, but I really hoped it wasn't going to be what it ended up being :(
You can pan left or right. Not in.

Holy moly I felt I was at a Mr. Universe contest by the end! It's weird...but I've never really equated buffness with strength. Looking at beef-cake I can't think of those guys actually doing anything with their muscles, just striking poses. The offensive line of the Steelers* are a bunch of big palooks with overhanging guts. I'd take them over Arrrnold any day. 

*Re the Steelers: 20 years ago I heard on TV John Madden in an idle moment calculate the combined weight of the Steelers' offensive line, then convert that figure to what they'd weigh...on Mars! (On Mars, you'd way approximately 38% of your weight here). Madden's boothmate was rendered speechless. 

Aye, the sepia toned Tulsi really is window trim, isn't she, while the boffoon king, who has nothing to fear from any of HIS pawns, sends out short epistles in all caps, demanding his minions scour every pot and pan for anyone the least bit different, then budget cut after budget cut, cutting the hearts out of everyone from the lowest barista to the CEO of IBM. Like the country's been carjacked...If I were an oracle, I'd say he'll di' alone. And if I were a warlock, I'd fill my used pot with ice beer, eye of newt, rot of rat, stir it round until it boils, yes, and I'd get Andre the Giant to play the fife as I chant the words:

Arianna arena dojo asiago woo,
Arianna arena dojo asiago woo!
BBs CCs Tupac ciao!
BBs CCs Tupac ciao.
Arianna dojo asiago woo!

Nice one! Congratulations, Daniel Bodily, on lucky 13 for NYT. This prior passenger found a PERFECTFIT today. Much less trying than your Monumental Centennial built up on 5/29/22, with support from Jeff Chen. https://www.nytimes.com/2022/05/28/crosswords/daily-puzzle-2022-05-29.html Keep 'em coming, O great SUDO!
TRIM does seem like a stretch. Decent puzzle though all the same. In-flight magazine theme was a tough act to follow

A solid puzzle with clues that were just far enough off the obvious to cause some stumbles, but with fills that were actually a PERFECT FIT. I especially liked the PAWN menacing the king.  No look-ups necessary and a feeling of satisfaction when the FINISH music played. 

Thank you, Daniel Bodily, and welcome to the 2nd day of the 2nd quarter of 2025.  Nice to see you back‚Äîwhat have you been doing with yourSELF? Whatever it was, I'm glad to see that it all worked out.

INT. WHITE HOUSE EAST ROOM - EVENING

ROBIN
(Excitedly)
Holy Basil Batman!
NEWT and the Wicked WARLOCK have double-crossed TULSI with an E-PISTLE
under the WINDOWTRIM in the East Room!

BATMAN
How do you know this Robin?
Have you checked her for any Bodily harm?  Are there any BUDGETCUTs?

ROBIN
(Rolls TULSI over)
No, I don't see any BUDGETCUTs, but she's surely DEMISED. 
I know because Commissioner Gordon set up a secret code in the NYTs Xword puzzle, remember?
Who would do such a thing to TULSI?!

BATMAN
Robin, I strongly suspect Kekius Maximus, he's a PERFECTFIT, the crazed inventor of the E-PISTLE.
(sniffing)
WOO!  Robin...I smell a RAT!

ROBIN
(Sighs)
No, that's probably just the ASIAGO you're smelling, Caped Crusader.

BATMAN
Oh, ROT.  Kekius Maximus is a SPORTSBUFF Robin, we're off to the ARENA!...STAT!

Fun puzzle. I was stuck with MATE as the threat to the king for a very long time. WINDOW TRIM gave me NEWT which helped me to PAWN and finally opened up that section.

DIAL ONE also tripped me up; I was sure it was DIALED O. Should've paid attention to the tense in the clue.

‚ÄúPan in‚Äù is wrong and it makes no sense.  A camera pans when the shot moves to the left or right.

‚ÄúZoom in‚Äù is what this clue is talking about.

5D ‚ÄúGet a closer shot‚Äù is flat out wrong. 

A pan is a shot where the camera moves horizontally around the axis on which it is mounted - left to right or right to left, but never closer or farther. 

The cinematic move in which the camera physically gets closer would be a dolly shot. A zoom is a shot in which the focal length of the lens changes dynamically during the shot, resulting in a portion of the image getting larger, which can have the effect of simulating the camera getting closer to the subject without the camera physically moving in relation to the subject. 

Of course, a dolly and a zoom can be combined in a single shot, which can have the effect of either intensifying the sense of increasing closeness, or counteracting it (the so-called dolly-counter-zoom made famous by Hitchcock in Vertigo, among many others.)

TL:dr - A camera shot can appear to get closer to its subject using either a dolly or a zoom, or both. But never a pan (unless, of course, that pan is combined with a dolly or a zoom, a technique that was rather common in films of the Sixties and Seventies, but tends to look awkward and unsophisticated to modern eyes.)

This is a rare slip up by the usually spot on NYT crossword editorial team.
why pots?

I found this harder than last Saturday's puzzle. I knew almost none of the trivia, the clueing was not on my wavelength, and things like ICE BEER or DIAL ONE were completely alien to me. I only got the theme once the grid was almost completely filled (with lookups, autocheck and a reveal of FIFE, whatever that is) so it was no help at all. I thought the theme was convoluted - two revealers? So many themed entries?

Not my day.

I came to ask at what scout camp do they build canoes (13A) -- but nevermind, I get it now. Lanyard didn't fit, which is the only camp craft I remember. Here is a great poem about that by Billy Collins. https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poems/50975/the-lanyard
A camera on a dolly, or tripod/bipod, pans from side to side. The motion of getting closer to the object being imaged is zoom, not pan.

My legal background nearly led to my (figurative) DEMISE, which I knew as a noun but not as a verb.  In English ‚Äî and hence Canadian ‚Äî common law, DEVISE is a verb used to mean transfer by will of an interest in real property (in contrast to BEQUEATH used to refer to a transfer by will of any other kind of property).

Otherwise, a TARIFFic lot of fun for a Wednesday puzzle.
Today's answer for 35D was a good example of "high comedy".
The rock star at 56 across has never been knighted....

I start strong when I work out, because I‚Äôm a BUFF OON.

Eye of NEWT me, WARLOCK.
Is it really Wednesday today? This crossword feels more like Thursday or Friday. I can usually do the Wednesday ones but didn't get anywhere with this one.

The theme was a PERFECT FIT for someone with a name like Bodily.  

As for 5 D, all of those PANIN complaints could have been eliminated by cluing it as [Half of an Italian sandwich].

5-D ‚ÄúPAN IN‚Äù is absolutely incorrect.  There is no such term in film making or photography.

Panning is when you turn or move the camera from side to side to see something different.  The term is never used to indicate zooming or moving the camera forward to get a tighter shot of the same subject.  Never.

This answer crops up in crosswords every now and then.  It apparently stems from an erroneous entry in a style book which misunderstood the usage in the source it referenced.

Please stop putting it into puzzles, as it only helps amplify this error.
Can someone explain ‚Äúbunk‚Äù / ROT to me? I thought it was going to be COT

Great puzzle! Mr. Bodily certainty embodies the qualities of a fine crossword constructor. 

So many complaints about PAN IN, ad nauseam. Aren‚Äôt we all used to this sort of license by now? Maybe not. I‚Äôm pretty sure most of us figured out the answer without too much difficulty.

Well... managed to work this one out, but must confess that I remained somewhat puzzled about the theme even when I was done. I mean I kind of get it, but some of them seemed a bit of a stretch. No big deal. One appropriate answer history search today was for BODILYHARM. Nope - never been in a puzzle and not even in the Xword Info word lists. And... my appropriate puzzle find today - an odd one. A Wednesday from December 3, 2003 by Bruce Adams. Four theme answers in that one: "Summary of Krzysztof's visit west of Warsaw?" HEHADLODZOFFUN "When Krzysztof got up south of Warsaw?" ATTHEKRAKOWDAWN "What Krzysztof was doing northwest of Warsaw?" DANZIGINTHEDARK "Purpose of Krzysztof's travels" POLISHVACATION Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=12/3/2003&g=5&d=D I'll shut up now. ....

This is one of the worst puzzles ever written.
Not even clever by half of a half of a half.
Dry riddles combined with definitions that are just plain inaccurate.

Am I in the minority or majority 
that got all jazzed when I saw the 
*length* of the clue at 1Down?

Daniel Bodily is a wizard of words,
opting for dense, intelligent themes
that push the limits of the day, but 
*somehow* hit the mark.
Bullseye!

Remember the rocket ship Sunday last year?
C‚Äômon! That was a framer!

I think the reason many of us are here,
is that - in order to fully enjoy the solve - 
we must be able to trust the puzzle.

NYT has earned that trust.
For me, anyway.

And Daniel Bodily is consistently,
bold, profoundly clever, and fair.

This was a tiny, meaty grid with *just* 
enough fat to make it a Wednesday!

How? How does he do it?

He‚Äôs a word wizard.

He wears a tall, sparkly cone hat with
golden letters that seem to magically swirl‚Ä¶
And he‚Äôs got a wand.
There‚Äôs got to be a wand involved.

The only sensible explanation.

Happy hump day all!

Wow! 
So many comments on PAN IN?
Really?

Now that the experts have weighed in,
we all can say, ‚ÄúHuh. I thought it seemed okay.‚Äù

And the crosses gave it to us anyway!

Such a bummer when 
a ton of puzzle is overlooked because
of one, singular, technically incorrect
(though commonly misused)
answer!

I tried to express my annoyance of the
flat-out, growing misuse of the word 
‚Äúliterally‚Äù
to my son. He‚Äôs 28. Ish.

He said I gotta get over it.
It‚Äôs *literally* been changed to mean
*not literally.‚Äù

The opposite.

I literally flew off the handle at that one.

No I didn‚Äôt.

There‚Äôs a point in this comment. 
Somewhere‚Ä¶

I think.

There was a time when that other endless circle of alphabet-soup groupings was itself fresh and novel - did they then call it the ‚ÄúNew Dial‚Äù? Yes, interesting to read about planting trees, but guessing early-American letter triplets, not so much.

Nevertheless, fun to play the puzzle I was dealt.
Took me longer to get this than usual for Wednesday. Didn't feel like it tho. It was an enjoyable fill.

Swole puzzle, Mr. Bodily! Although I had never considered Ice beer before, as soon as I worked it out from the crosses, it seemed obvious: to concentrate the alcohol content by partially freezing the beer, and removing the ice. The ethanol, of course, doesn't freeze, and so is left behind. Per Wikipedia, the process originated in Germany (Eisbock), but really took off in Canada. Probably because it's cold there. Another reason to love my neighbors to the south. (Canada has, in recent decades, become a major producer of Eiswein, or ice wine, as well--but in that case the freezing occurs at a different point in the production, and for a different purpose.) But here's the spin: the process of concentrating the alcohol through partial freezing is known as "jacking"--when done to fermented cider, the result is called "applejack." So ice beer is a brew which could be said to be BEERJACKED! https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/jack#Verb
DEVISED I'm familiar with but not DEMISED.  Of course TRIM gave me no choice.

A very doable and enjoyable crossword for me today. 
I eventually had to reveal TULSI/TUPAC and I had no idea what the theme was, the solutions looked random to me -  JACKED and CUT didn't seem related.
 But I'm not bothered by knowing the themes!

As I read the comments I sense the Dark Side.

We went through every New Deal program we knew and at the end CCC.

Daniel, PANIN and TBAR are dated: FYI.

Thank you, nice job.

A moderately challenging puzzle, which is about right for a Wednesday, though count me among those who cringed at 5 D. I won‚Äôt explain why the clue is incorrect for that answer since others have done that. To those who say it‚Äôs a common-enough phrase, I argue‚Ä¶I thought the New York Times was supposed to be the paper of record. In a time when sloppy thinking has brought so much harm to the world, especially this year, I think we should strive for as much precise language as possible. The CW has conventions to indicate slang and so on, so Iif a fill needs to be PAN IN to make the grid work, perhaps that‚Äôs the way to go?

Quite crunchy for a Wednesday, as I see others mention. Enjoyed the theme, though it‚Äôs been years since any part of me felt TONED. Perhaps my biceps will tighten up a little now I‚Äôm humping barrow loads of alpaca poo around every day. 

I see there have been a few POT references in crosswords recently, the 35D type, not the 24A. I have no problem with that, but feel slightly miffed that the emus took so long debating a comment of mine responding to someone‚Äôs mention of the lyrics in White Rabbit, that they delayed letting it through for 4 days! I mentioned another illicit substance, oft clued in the grid, known by three letters. Sigh. There is no logic. A little bit like‚Ä¶
It begins to look like PAN IN is akin to ICE RAIN, terms used somewhere but maybe only in Crosslandia.

I'm always happy to learn new words from doing the crossword...it's a big reason I do them.

I'm not so sure about DEMISED...it makes my skin crawl, frankly.

Still enjoyed the puzzle!
As long as we're being pedantic, I think the proper term for 5D would be "DOLLY IN". Zoom refers to adjusting the focal length of the lens, not moving the camera.

Good morning! I was daunted by the clue and all the highlighted entries at 1D, so I decided to ignore it, and just go on about the puzzle. Strategy worked for me - a decent time, and the 1D answer and theme fell into place about halfway through.
Impressive to work in so many themed entries. Nice Wednesday.
I checked with my film major daughter about pan in. ‚ÄúDolly in or zoom in. Pan is side to side.‚Äù  Sloppy edit NYT.

My opinion?  I'm glad you asked.

A kind of mediocre theme,
with a harder-than-normal-Wednesday fill.

I didn't much like PAN IN, 
but I thought DEMISED was worse,

But, really not worth complaining about.

"Then, why are you commenting?"

Well, you asked for my opinion, and I didn't want to be rude.

Overall, a decent puzzle.
CIAO, Bella!

Because it's April, I expected the "issuance" in 32D to be a REFund, not yet another burdensome REGulation. I will refrain from making a case for agency BUDGET CUTs, but it's amusing that those two entries crossed.
Who says USED POT?
Nicely executed theme. Especially impressive to have six theme entries! But I did feel that it made the rest of the fill somewhat awkward.

Ma and PA NIN, you've got a lovely daughter,
Girls as sharp as her are somethin' rare
But it's sad, she doesn't love me now
She's made it clear enough, it ain't no good to pine

The Civilian Conservation Corps was such a cool part of the New Deal. I hate that the American Climate Corps program was cancelled by the new administration. These kind of programs are such a good investment in the future, I dream of a day where conservation isn't politicized and can receive the bipartisan support it did during the 60's and 70's.
good puzzle
The impact of the CCC really is amazing. So many wonderful, huge forests we have today include somewhere in them a sign or plaque crediting the program.

I have been working in the film and TV industry for 25 years. Pan is left and right movement only. Lots of ways to clue this without getting the meaning of the word wrong. Very disappointing from the NYT crossword. (Next you‚Äôll be asking the camera to tilt left.)
I was mostly on the same wavelength as the constructor, but was stumped by ICEbeer and FOAMpad, and just plain forgot FIFE. Good puzzle!
Perfectly constructed with not a square wasted and a nice, strong theme.  Well done, Mr. Bodily!
Hate to be that guy, but moving in for a closer shot is to zoom or push in. Panning is moving horizontally with the camera (from "panorama"). So "pan in" isn't right here and doesn't really exist.

@Sam Corbin, today's column is üî• from top to bottom! 

As usual, the photo is a PERFECT FIT (though maybe more straightforward than some). Speaks to my (and your?) shoehorning attempts at 62A, but mostly I love the anthropomorphizing nature of the bears' "expressions"! 

The light, punny touches in your prose hit just the right notes. Especially loved your 10D explanation -- I could feel it picking up speed as it went along.

And I'm so with you on 55D! (My first exposure as a new New Yorker to "SRO" was for the term "single room occupancy", much more prevalent in the UWS neighborhood where I lived than tickets to a Broadway show...)

Pretty NEAT, if I do say so! I'll stop fan-girling now.  :)
The mini for Wednesday, April 2 has a wrong answer to a clue. Peter Pan uses fairy dust, not pixie dust, to fly.
I attended many a scout camp, and we sure never crafted any CANOEs.

Awesome job and great theme too! I solved it in 38 minutes with no dictionary and/or help like usual. Obviously, I appreciate when no current ‚Äúpoliticians‚Äù are involved in the puzzles. As for the Mini, I concur with Rebecca from Wisconsin that it was Fairy Dust and NOT Pixie Dust! I hope my fellow NYTers have a Wonderful Wednesday and Namaste!!

If you start strong when you work out, are you a BUFFOON?

My workouts usually end with ICE followed by a heating PAD.  

For newer solvers, Daniel‚Äôs debut NYT puzzle, a Thursday collaboration with Jeff Chen, is worth a look.  3/17/22.
I had gotshOT for a while. Those are the hits on my mind, I suppose. What a BUFFOON I was‚Ä¶

Had fun with this one, though I feel like no one who has USED POT would ever phrase it that way. Not to incriminate myself or anything‚Ä¶

P.S. I was so proud of myself for blind filling 46A as ‚Äúlitmus tesT‚Äù with only the final T to go on. The real answer was better, but I liked mine darn it!
Boooo to "Pan in". A pan and a zoom are not the same, and this is at best a marginal clue and answer pair.

Hmmm...  A camera 'Pan' movement isn't getting closer. It's a horizontal movement, specifically one where the camera rotates on a stand, instead of moving the camera on a dolly. It's definitely not 'getting a closer shot' in any definition.


Also, these crossword authors really love EBB and SRO. I've lost count of how many times they've shown up lately (though I'm sure someone on the wide web is tracking such stats)

It seems like the quest for a high themer count resulted in some less than stellar fill. Even if some people say PAN IN, it's still a little bleh. How about "Add an "o" to the end of this and you've got a delicious grilled sandwich"? Then I guess we'd have to debate PANINo vs PANINi.

Harder for me than usual for a Wednesday, but I solved it correctly without assistance. Clever puzzle with a lot of thematic content. TULSI/TUPAC crossing at the U is cute.

RERUN rather than REAIR slowed me down.

HEARTS is usually classified as a "trick-avoidance" game. But it is a card game in which tricks are taken, so the clue is OK.

Yeah, Sam, I think you're not wrong that the beer marketers tacked the word "ice" onto some of their product because it sounds appealing.   I mean yes, there is said to be a whole process suggested by the word "ice" or "ice brewed", but I doubt it escaped their notice that the word sounds appealing next to the word "beer".

I really enjoyed this one. Clever theme, and the clues that some folks didn‚Äôt like seemed okay to me. 
Thanks Daniel.
Clue 11D is wrong.  ‚ÄúDemise‚Äù means end, or death.  The word you want for this meaning is ‚Äúdevise.‚Äù
Nice! Had me really aggravated --- then it all fit together. My favorite kind of puzzle.

The first clue gave me a smile, since the Manet painting is seen frequently in musical environments and especially in flute studios. The clue used the silly English language name of the painting ‚ÄúThe Young Flautist‚Äù, rather than the painter‚Äôs name ‚ÄúLe Fifre‚Äù - ‚ÄúThe Fifer.‚Äù The uniform and instrument both show that this is a military fifer, and not a flutist. The same problem would occur if a painting of a bugler playing a bugle in military uniform were called ‚ÄúThe Trumpeter.‚Äù

The position of the fingers (showing a nominal F natural being played) is so accurate and natural that it proves that the young musician sent to Manet‚Äôs studio was really a fifer and that Manet knew how to see as well as how to paint.

Archibald Willard‚Äôs famous painting ‚ÄúThe Spirit of ‚Äô76‚Äù, aka ‚ÄúYankee Doodle‚Äù, includes two side drummers and a fifer, showing a flag bearer in the background on a battlefield. The military role of bugles, drums, fifes (and bagpipes) along with flags and standards sets them apart from music and art and makes them signalers, coordinators, morale boosters, and, often, vulnerable targets in traditional warfare.

So call the kid a fifer, he was (in the Imperial Guard of Napoleon III, according to his uniform).

Three cheers for the CCC.

DEMISED was nearly my demise in this puzzle. 
Ergo, my FINISH was not so STRONG.

Imagine the constructor painting himself into a corner and being forced to come up with a clue for PANIN, or otherwise rip up the puzzle and start over.  Is there a good way to clue PANIN?

Perhaps the editors said "Aah let's just go with it and take our lumps."
No one "uses pot".

Maybe it should've been clued as [Anais's father]: PA NIN.

I'm sorry to see our Wisconsin friend's post removed from its top billing.  While it was off topic, it was clearly popular with the readers here. 

Or maybe [Italian sandwich with a small bite out of it]: PANIN.

Judging from other comments here, I suspect that I'm not the only former TV/Film cameraman solving this puzzle.

The editors missed one here. Basic camera movement taught in intro classes...Dolly, truck, pan, zoom, etc.

"Pan" is a stationary camera position with the direction of the "lens" of the camera moving from left to right or vice versa. :)

Today‚Äôs puzzle took me 9:47

Wednesday, March 30, 1994 took me 14:36 (and I turned on auto check to find two errors so could have taken quite a bit longer). 

Not criticizing today‚Äôs puzzle at all, it was fun, just comparing to the ‚Äúgood ol‚Äô days‚Äù.

Another boo for PAN IN. Zoom in or dolly in, but pan left or right. 

I shake my fist.
I'd say trim is a synonym of fit or toned, but not really strong. Doesn't matter, crossword logic is more loose association most of the time.
PAN IN is not a thing! A pan is a left to right or right to left motion. You can zoom in, you can dolly in, you can push in. But you cannot pan in!

As someone who played HEARTS on parents' Windows XP computer, that clue thew me because I think of it as a game where you *don't* take tricks. But I suppose it's not inaccurate.

WINDOWTRIM was tricky, especially as it was crossed with PANIN, ANDRE, and DEMISED. Learned some new things today!

For those interested, I'm heading back to Antarctica-- this time to Palmer Station on the peninsula. Our boat has decent internet so I'm sure I'll be getting my crossword fill as we cross the Drake Passage!

I know commenters are arguing that because "pan" is often mistakenly used as a generic term for any camera adjustment by people trying to sound in the know, we should accept "pan in" as legit here based on usage.

I usually agree with that linguistic logic, but in appropriating a term of art and then misusing it, they've muddied the water on film sets, where the terms pan, tilt, dolly, and zoom still need to be used with precision. 

So, unlike "literally," it's still worth calling it out as wrong. For the time being, anyway.
Talk about PANdemics!  Wow! you'd think it was the only clue in the puzzle, so many commenters  jumped on it.  It was fun to solve. Lighten up.

Nice puzzle!  Not sure it was a PERFECTFIT, but I thought it was definitely NEAT. 

My favorite clue/answer pair was 5D, PANIN. It's the name of my world-renown professional photography studio and having it show up in the New York times crossword puzzle makes me feel very seen. I hope it makes Lewis's top five clues of the year list. üòÇüòÇüòÇ  

I actually really did like the clue for APE only because I hate the way it's normally clued. I don't even know why but it really bothers me the way it's so often clued as a verb. 

And I really liked BONO on top of BONN. I wish it could have gone further, in the vein of those puzzles where you only change one letter and keep making new words. I don't remember what those are called. Actually, I think there was a puzzle last year or so that had that as a theme. Or maybe I'm just too giddy with glee over having such a great clue, for PANIN.

For 21A, I briefly thought how everyone in the comments was going to be upset because the plural in SEPIATONEs didn't match the other theme answers. Duh!  I'm trying to be better but unfortunately, I didn't catch it until I didn't get the happy music, but I found it pretty quickly when I went back.  

Now please excuse me, I have to go put a PANIN the oven for dinner...

When I saw PANIN I though "Whoo boy are the Resident Correctors and Defenders going to have a big day today!"

Yup.

I'm surprised there weren't more complaints about STRONG being a hint for TRIM. They're correlated but... whatever.

Puzzles like this which have unpleasing spots (especially in the themers) leave me disappointed.
DEMISED? Now that is a real crossword puzzle word. On a Wednesday no less
There is no such thing as 5 down.
Icy what you did there!
Daniel Bodily is one to avoid in the future, got it.

While some of you were enjoying various ways to (not) USE POT in college, I was trying to figure out the cheapest way to go out on a Wednesday. Dime beer night at The Bluebird was upped to 15 cents around the time ICEBEER became popular. Gotta get your nickel's worth!

Pots and pans notwithstanding, my beef is "ton" as the approximate weight of the Liberty Bell.  Nothing weighs ton.  It might weigh about a ton, or one ton, or, heck, even 0.57888493 tons, but not just ton.

Today is my 60th Birthday, and my 605-day win streak is going to end on a WEDNESDAY PUZZLE!

I haven‚Äôt seen GUARDIANS OF THE GALAXY, so I don‚Äôt know that character‚Äôs last name. And I wish I was more learned in the New Deal tree-planting plan, but I‚Äôm not. The center of this puzzle (a Wednesday, no less!) has me stumped!

Seven empty boxes are going to ruin my 60th birthday.
A real puzzler! My time was well over my Wednesday average, but had to FINISH STRONG to keep my streak.
I never knew ROT as a synonym for nonsense. I first filled in 31D as ‚Äúcot‚Äù but I quickly realized that was incorrect.

Not a fan of this puzzle. I feel like the constructor had a neat theme going but couldn‚Äôt fill it with actual words (or words that made sense) so they used things like PAN IN, ROT for bunk, ICEBEER‚Ä¶
I guess I‚Äôm late to the PAN IN pile on, but consider me equally furious! :-)
Hey, at least, for me, PANIN wasn't French, or a Marvel or Star Trek movie or sports hint, or '...quaintly', so it's all good! Took me a while, but I got there. On to Thursday!

Clearly need a new crew in the crossword editorial department. Even with Will back they continue to deteriorate. 

And no, nobody cares about your opinion Harry Aconda.
This comment refers to BAFFOON clued as [Goofball]

@Joya 

BUFFOON

@Sam Lyons 

Cinderella has left the building.  The men's final four has all four Regional number 1 seeds.  The women's has three number 1s and one number 2 that just happens to be UConn.

@N.E. Body 

If you're using a cell phone, the "1" is optional when we type in a number, but it's actually added by the phone software if we don't, so we don't generally see it. Landlines and VOIP phones still have to use 1+number.

Actually if you go back far enough, you turned a crank and told the operator you wanted long distance, and somewhat later you could just dial 0 yourself, then tell the operator you wanted the long distance operator.

We got the 1+ when we got area codes and wanted to call someone in a different area code, otherwise you could call locally using just the seven-digit phone number‚Ä¶ and it could still be long distance. Then they made it complicated with overlying area codes and now you have to "dial" 10-digit phone numbers (plus the 1 in front if necessary).

@jennie  An initial "1" wasn't the country code back in those days. It was a prefix that indicated you wanted to call outside of the local office of the telco. You then followed it with (exchange   number) to dial a toll call that was not long distance, or (area code   exchange   number) to place a long distance call that might or might not be a toll call (long distance information is the best example of that -- an 800-number actually generated a billing entry which was subsequently discarded!).
@Bruce  But first you had to make sure the other ‚Äúparty‚Äù that you shared your line with, wasn‚Äôt on the phone. That‚Äôs me, aging myself‚Ä¶
We used to ask for Hilltop 323 to get my grandmother on the line. Then check to see if the neighbors were on the line too (party line).

@JayTee

The  1 is the Country code for USA.  If you are calling to South Africa use  27.  Or Russia use  7, or England use  44.  

So the clue only works if you are calling a long distance number in the USA.  You can now direct dial to almost anywhere in the world!  Pretty amazing.  I think about my ancestors who emigrated from Europe to USA 200   years ago.  They never saw their families again, and letters took months.  Now we video chat with friends all over the world, and only have to worry about time zone differences.

@Bruce If it‚Äôs in the dictionary, it‚Äôs fine for the puzzle. https://idioms.thefreedictionary.com/pan+in You know and I know that it‚Äôs strictly not correct. But when usage is great enough that it appears in a dictionary, a second meaning evolves. And the dictionary legitimizes it. Purists are shocked, especially if they work in an industry where the word is a term of art. People who realize that pan is short for panorama are less likely to use the wrong word. Both usages reside side by side in the language. That‚Äôs how language evolves. Some people will make it their hill to die on. That‚Äôs fine for them. But crosswords reflect common usage. And in common usage, PAN IN is fine. Or at least tolerated.

I am, or at least I used to be, quite the beer snob. In 2011 or so craft breweries started popping up all over Poland (Artezan and Pinta being some of the first). These days Polish people make all kinds of beer, of different styles from all over the world: the US, Germany, Belgium (the tripel and quadrupel from Komes are heavenly), New Zealand, Japan, etc. Sometimes I think it's easier to find something exotic than much more mainstream, like a simple pils or lager (unless you're prepard to drink the industrially made quaff, which no beer snob will do). I do enjoy weaker beers though, and non-alcoholic ones, too, if they have been brewed properly and taste like actual beer, and not like the overly sweet, industrial variety with an unpleasant aftertaste.

Joe,

News coverage is supposed to be factual, and the words chosen should be accurate and precise.

Crosswords are word puzzles, and the words chosen should be playful and confusing, with plenty of room for common if technically inaccurate usage.

SRSLY!

@Barry Ancona 

Yeah, but‚Ä¶there is a line, albeit a subjective one. As Bruce from Atlanta said last night:

‚ÄúIt's just plain incorrect.

It's‚Ä¶extremely common for people to confuse ‚Äòits‚Äô with ‚Äòit's,‚Äô too, and you can always figure out what was meant from context, but that doesn't make it acceptable usage.‚Äù

To me, ‚Äúpan in‚Äù crosses that line, as clued, and I would appreciate it if the editors stopped allowing it, as clued, or required more innovative clueing for it.

Warren,

Fine with me if you don't like PAN IN as clued, but Bruce's analogy doesn't work. "It's" and "its" look the same in the grid (unless there is a rebus), and they would not (or should not) be misused in a clue. If PAN IN crosses a line, it is a different line.

@Warren 

PAN IN is certainly in an early stage of acceptance, but there‚Äôs definitely something there. Any change in the language comes about because people initially misuse a word. For example, a couple hundred years ago, you‚Äôd have been laughed at for writing ‚Äútoday‚Äù.  Now, you‚Äôd be laughed at for writing ‚Äúto-day.‚Äù

‚ÄúPan‚Äù was born of ‚Äúpanorama‚Äù or ‚Äúpanoramic.‚Äù Film industry workers and film buffs know this and are up in arms that people use it for zooming (or dollying) in and out instead of moving side to side like you‚Äôre supposed to. 

The rest of the world doesn‚Äôt know of that derivation, so it doesn‚Äôt dawn on them that PAN IN might be wrong. And they don‚Äôt care. And they outnumber film insiders. And they will win out in the end. 

Why?  Because English. 

No, let me correct that. 

Because language.

@Sam Corbin What did Ben Brantley do after seeing a truly terrible performance? He turned his PAN IN.

@Sam Corbin Pan In cannot be used correctly because it is a mis-phrasing of camera directions.  It can only be used as "Pan right" or Pan left" - horizontal movements only.  
I have been working on movie sets for over 40 years, these directions are uniquely precise so we do not misunderstand each other - just like the NATO alphabet.

@Nathan I went bananas when I saw this and sent to multiple peers. Over the years I have cringed through many instances of ‚ÄúPan up‚Äù and ‚ÄúPan down‚Äù‚Ä¶ never thought I‚Äôd see ‚Äúpan in‚Äù ‚Äî let alone in the NYT!
